isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 570 / HT 570 Diesel Engine Diagnostic Manual - 2004 Emissions with EGR - Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics - Test Procedures - 13. Fuel Pressure and Aerated Fuel

svcprocinfo.para: To check for correct fuel pressure and aerated fuel

item.para: Ask the operator if the amber WATER IN FUEL lamp was on during vehicle operation.

If engine has an optional Engine Fuel Pressure (EFP) sensor, ask the operator if the amber FUEL FILTER lamp was on during vehicle operation. If the lamp was on, change the fuel filter and retest for poor engine operation.
If unit was run out of fuel, make sure the fuel system was primed. See "Priming the Fuel System" in Section 4 for procedure.
See "Combustion Leaks to Fuel" in Section 4 if all three of the following conditions are noted:
Fuel system will not prime
White to black exhaust smoke
Pulsating fuel pressure
Fuel pressure test gauge
Fuel Pressure Test Kit
1 to 5 gallon bucket
Fuel/Oil Pressure Test Coupler

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the "Safety Information" section of this manual.

step1.para:
See "DT 466 Performance Specifications" - Appendix A or "DT 570 and HT 570 Performance Specifications"
- Appendix B for fuel pressure specifications and record on Diagnostic Form.

note.para: If engine is equipped with optional Engine Fuel Pressure (EFP) sensor, use EST with MasterDiagnostics® software to monitor fuel pressure. Compare the EST values to gauge readings.

caution.para: Be sure to place a rag or suitable container under the fuel pressure test valve when bleeding the fuel rail. Dispose of fuel in a correct container clearly marked DIESEL FUEL according to local regulations.

note.para: Engine fuel can be a threat to the environment. Never dispose of engine fuel by putting it in the trash, pouring on the ground, in the sewers, in streams, or bodies of water.
Engines are equipped with a fuel pressure test valve in the form of either a Shrader valve or a diagnostic coupling.
If the engine is equipped with a Shrader valve, use the Fuel Pressure Test Adapter.
If the engine is equipped with a diagnostic coupling, adapt the Fuel/Oil Pressure Test Coupler to the Fuel Pressure Gauge.

figure.caption: Fuel Pressure Gauge to fuel pressure test adapter

step1.para: Connect Fuel Pressure Gauge with shut-off valve and clear 3/8" diameter hose to test valve.
Route the clear hose into a drain pan.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:
When routing test line, do not crimp the line, run the line too close to moving parts, or let the line touch hot engine surfaces.

step1.para: Start or crank the engine for 20 seconds. Measure the fuel pressure with the shut-off valve closed. Open the shut-off valve to check for aeration.

note.para: Breaking any fuel system joint will induce air into the fuel system. The air should pass in a short period of time. As fuel pressure is relieved, a steady stream of fuel without air bubbles indicates the fuel is not aerated.
If a Fuel Pressure Gauge with shut-off valve and clear 3/8" diameter hose is not available to check for aeration, see alternative test "Checking for Aerated Fuel using Spare Fuel Line."

item.para: If fuel pressure is below specification and fuel is not aerated, replace the fuel filter and clean the strainer. Test the fuel pressure again.
If fuel is aerated, see "Aerated Fuel" in Section 4.
If fuel pressure is still low and fuel is not aerated after replacing the fuel filter and cleaning the strainer, do "Operation of the Fuel Pump Test."
If fuel pressure is in specification and the fuel is not aerated, do not continue testing the fuel system. Continue to the next diagnostic test.

svcsubproc.title: Checking for Aerated Fuel using Spare Fuel Line

note.para: This is an alternative test. Do this procedure, only if Fuel Pressure Gauge with shut-off valve is not available.

item.para: Spare fuel line (filter housing to fuel supply pump)
Clear plastic line
Hose clamp (2)

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the "Safety Information" section of this manual.

step1.para: Remove fuel supply line from suction side of fuel pump and fuel filter housing.

item.para: Use spare fuel line. (Make sure both sleeve seals are good.) Cut a 3 inch section from the center of the fuel line. Install clear plastic line in place of removed section and secure plastic line with clamps.

note.para: The mechanic is expected to keep the fuel test line for future diagnostics. Expense the fuel test line as an essential tool and keep it with other diagnostic tools. Warranty will not cover the cost of the fuel test line.
Verify that sleeve seals are in good condition.

item.para: For Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics, crank engine for 20 seconds and check for air bubbles in the clear plastic line.
For Performance Diagnostics, run engine at high idle, no load and check for air bubbles in the clear plastic line.

note.para: Initially, fuel will be aerated due to draining fuel from filter housing and strainer in previous test.

item.para: If fuel is aerated check for a leak in the suction side of fuel system. See "Aerated Fuel" in Section 4.
If fuel is not aerated and fuel pressure is good, continue with next test.
If fuel is not aerated and fuel pressure is low, do "Operation of Fuel Pump".

step1.para: Remove fuel test line and install original fuel line.

note.para: Verify that sleeve seals are in good condition.

item.para: Vacuum Pump And Gauge (kit)
Hose clamp
Fuel pressure test gauge
Fuel Pressure Test Kit
Fuel/Oil Pressure Test Coupler
1 to 5 gallon bucket

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the "Safety Information" section of this manual.

note.para: The fuel pressure gauge with the inline shut-off valve is still connected to the fuel pressure test valve. If shut-off valve is not opened, test will result in false readings. Do the following procedure:

step1.para: Disconnect fuel line (suction side) from fuel filter housing.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:
When routing test line, do not crimp the line, run the line too close to moving parts, or let the line touch hot engine surfaces.

step1.para: Slide test hose onto fuel line and secure with hose clamp or use cone adapter (vacuum pump kit) that fits into end of fuel line.
Insert vacuum pump nozzle into test hose.
Crank engine, check gauge reading, and record on Diagnostic Form.

item.para: If less than 12 in Hg., check steel line and test connections between the air vacuum test gauge and fuel pump. Verify integrity of test hose adapter
If vacuum is still below specification, replace the fuel pump following procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
If greater than 12 in Hg., the fuel pump is working. Replace fuel regulator and retest fuel pressure.
If fuel pressure is still low after replacing the fuel pump and regulator, check for restriction between the filter housing and fuel tank.
